0.text:
Emma by Jane Austen.
This is the story of Emma Woodhouse, the pretty,

3.text:
charming and much-loved youngest daughter
of a wealthy family in regency rural England.

7.text:
Emma runs her house, Hartfield, for her Father
and she's really the queen of her own domain

12.text:
- but of course that domain is still pretty
limited for a woman of that time, to the domestic

16.text:
sphere. And because her father is pretty demanding
and controlling at times, she doesn't have

20.text:
the opportunity to travel or to see any of
the sights of Europe, or even the more accessible

24.text:
pleasures of the English Spa Towns. So she
has to make her own amusement, and the amusement

29.text:
that she chooses is matchmaking. Emma believes
that there is a pefect match for evey person

33.text:
and that she is the one to help them to find
it. So she makes friends with this girl called

37.text:
Harriet who goes to a local finishing school
and is of questionable parentage. They become

41.text:
great friends and Harriet is sort of in love
with this guy called Robert Martin. But Emma

46.text:
disapporves because Martin is a farmer and
she thinks that Harriet should aim much higher,

50.text:
specifically for the slightly creepy but very
eligible young vicar Mr Elton. She thinks

56.text:
that Elton likes Harriet because he complimented
this painting that Emma did of her but in

60.text:
fact it turns out that he was complimenting
Emma herself. Enter Mr Knightley, Emma's kind

64.text:
and wise brother-in-law and incidentally her
closest friend who - spolier alert - she has

69.text:
some intense chemistry with. He's pretty disapproving
of her match-making activities and also her

74.text:
attitute towards the Misses Bates, some genteel
but impoverished local ladies. In the fairly

79.text:
limited social circles of Highbury, Emma feels
duty bound to attend the occassional card

83.text:
party or evening at their house. But she is
bored to tears by how much they talk about

87.text:
their young neice Jane Fairfax who is far
too reserved and virtuous for Emma's taste.

91.text:
Frank Churchill, a rather dashing young man,
arrives in the neighbourhood and he really

94.text:
hits it off with Emma. They make plans to
go to a famous viewpoint called Box Hill and

98.text:
invite the Misses Bates and Jane Fairfax along.
But unfortunately everything ends in tears

102.text:
at the picnic when Emma and Frank get carried
away and manage to offend everybody in their

106.text:
own special way. My Knightley thinks this
is badly done, but his disapproval of Emma

110.text:
soon turns to concern when he finds that Frank
Churchill and Jane Fairfax have been secretly

114.text:
corresponding and having a clandestine affair
all along. The thing is though, Emma isn't

118.text:
that heartbroken because it turns out that
the person she's always had feelings for is

121.text:
Mr Knightley himself. So after this rollercoaster
of emotions, the book ends in true Austen

126.text:
fashion with multiple weddings. What more
could you ask for? Hope that you've enjoyed

130.text:
this video and are having a great Booktube-A-Thon.
Thanks for watching!
